content:
Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

content:
David, I think what I said is that the folders seem to be in the files you suggested / I mentioned but I couldn't post images of them to the forum. Something I don't get about the Browse button. I didn't have time to work on it today. Here's what I plan to try tomorrow:

Copy the Thunderbird profile from old PC to the HDD. Copy the old pop.earthlink.net folder and the old Local Folders folder to the HDD Install all three those to the new PC, using %appdata% for Thunderbird.

Edit the profile on the new PC so that the file paths in Account Settings point to the copied over files, i.e.: 

   the path for Message Storage > Local Directory points to the pop.earthlink.net folder;    the path for Local Folders points to the Local Folders folder.

Seems logical. Hope it works! Thanks for your patience!

content:
Woo hoo! Successfully installed TBird on new PC today, 4/23/25 @ 3:42 PM EDT, with 21,564 historical messages! Some of those are extremely valuable to me! Also sends, receives, and has all address books.

I copied the "Thunderbird" profile on the old PC, using the %appdata% method and pasted it to the new PC. I then briefly brought up TBird and edited Server Settings to the files that contained my folders and Local Folders and closed TBird again. Then I moved those files to the new PC and finally brought up Thunderbird. Voila! The data was there!

Many thanks to David for patiently sticking with me!

DavidF

content:
I was glad to assist. Free beer for everyone. :)

Here's a tip: do backups on occasion to ensure all is good. Here are steps I use:


BACKUP

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

RESTORE

  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there

content:
re :I don't want to upgrade to 102

Even that version is somewhat old. After 102* there was 115* and now it's using 128*

Some people had issues mainly because they could not find things as layout altered. Personally, I had no problems.


re :How do I save all my emails, drafts, and sent messages if it's necessary to delete and reinstall the same version?

Uninstalling and reinstalling Thunderbird means just doing this for the program and it does not mean the Thunderbird profile folders which are not installed in the same location.

However: it's always advisable to perform a backup prior to doing anything major whether reinstalling or prior to updating to a newer major version of Thunderbird eg: from 91* to 102* etc.

Easy to do a backup.

  1. Exit Thunderbird
  2. In windows search type : '%Appdata% - see image below as guide
  3. Select : %Appdata% file folder
  4. Select: 'Roaming' folder
  5. Copy the 'Thunderbird' folder to a suitable location eg: external drive

re :Win 11 Pro ver 23H2, upgraded from Win 10. If you are suffering from the Windows 11 OS thin scrollbar:

  • settings, visual effects, enable scrollbar.

More info: https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/why-is-the-scroll-bar-in-windows-11-so-narrow-in/32a233d3-8453-4ee9-85c3-ba1a55a63dc3

It's also possible you maybe experiencing an old bug, but you would need to update to a more recent version because old versions do not get any special fixes. They would need to occur in a current release.

When you want to choose a version to update in 102* please make sure you choose one which is ok for update and not just manual initial download.

All versions are available here: http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/

content: Do you have Norton Antivirus installed as a Third Party Anti-Virus software? Some of these SMTP connection errors are Anti-virus related. You will need to check your settings if you're running Norton and make sure that you have created an exception for Thunderbird. You could also suspend the AV software for a short time and see if your previous errors continue - or start Windows in 'Safe Mode with Networking' as a diagnostic.

content:
I can send no emails. Some emails that show in the inbox show a blank screen and can not be deleted. All messages I send come back with an end of message error and SMTP blocked (see attached).

First of all, make sure you do have a backup of your Thunderbird profile. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile

Chances are that Bitdefender is messing things up. Therefore create an exception in Bitdefender for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the Bitdefender real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile

Once done that you can try to fix Inbox. Right-click Inbox in the folder pane - Properties - Repair Folder

No matter what I do or what I deleteincluding shutdown after every delete, when I reinstall it comes back with the total and Faulty Thunderbird

You can reinstall the application as many times as you want, it won't change a thing. All your data such as messages, passwords and user preferences, and changes made while you use Thunderbird, are stored in a special folder called a profile. Your profile folder is stored in a separate place from the Thunderbird program, so that if something ever goes wrong with Thunderbird your information will still be there. It also means that you can uninstall Thunderbird and reinstall without losing your settings and data.

If none of the above fixes the problems, you can still try to create a new profile, and start from scratch. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/using-multiple-profiles
creator: christ1

content:
still get the end of message, SMTP blocked when I try to send or rply to emails.

Try to start Windows 10 in safe mode with networking enabled. Still in Windows safe mode, start Thunderbird in safe mode. Does the problem go away?

Windows safe mode disables anti-virus software. This is a troubleshooting step, not a solution.

If I use multple profiles will this still keep the original

Yes, it will. And you do have multiple profiles already, don't you. Having said that, make sure you do have recent profile backups though.

is the new profile likely to bypass the SMTP port 587 error do you think?

I don't know. What is your email provider? And what are the server settings required by your email provider?

Also, please post your Troubleshooting Information. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡, then select Help > Troubleshooting Information. Press the "Copy text to clipboard button" and paste the information into your reply.
creator: christ1

content:
The "SMTP blocked" part of the error message you get is unclear whether it means the SMTP server is blocking you or the incoming server of the recipient is blocking your SMTP server. The "Please check the message and try again" part, however, seems to indicate the problem is with the message itself and that your SMTP server is refusing to send it because there is something about your message that the SMTP server doesn't like.

It could be that your SMTP server has become more strict and now requires messages sent through it to be sent from the same email address that you use to authenticate to the server, for example. Do the messages giving you this error have a "From" address different from the username you use to authenticate with the SMTP server?
creator: DavidGG

content:
DavidGG said
The "SMTP blocked" part of the error message you get is unclear whether it means the SMTP server is blocking you or the incoming server of the recipient is blocking your SMTP server. The "Please check the message and try again" part, however, seems to indicate the problem is with the message itself and that your SMTP server is refusing to send it because there is something about your message that the SMTP server doesn't like.

Agreed.

It could be that your SMTP server has become more strict and now requires messages sent through it to be sent from the same email address that you use to authenticate to the server, for example. Do the messages giving you this error have a "From" address different from the username you use to authenticate with the SMTP server?

content:
You need to authenticate with the outgoing server for sending messages just like you need to authenticate with the incoming server in order to receive them. The most common way to do that is with a username and password that the mail client stores so you don't have to type them every time. The username is usually the full email address or the part of the email address preceding the '@' sign associated with the mail account. You may check what username you're using for the SMTP server in you Outgoing Server (SMTP) settings. Check the screenshot in the following help article if you have trouble finding that:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/cannot-send-messages

Your SMTP server could now be requiring that the "From" address of your messages be the same as the email address used as the account username, and refuse to send your messages if you don't do that.

content: Problem solved just a couple of hours ago after weeks of stress. In this case Thunderbird is clean, not a program fault. After finally speaking with the SEO of my domain host who subsequently spoke to their server engineer it was found that the server for that one a/c had a firewall rule which automatically fired up and blocked outgoing messages. This was corrected and now works fine. My host has apologised for this not being spotted at the initial stage of checking and the "not our fault" attitude and blaming my email client or AV company. It resulted with them extending my a/c for a further year FOC. Thank you all for your assistance. Denis.

content: your screenshot is showing six profiles. Since thunderbird uses only one, it may be that five of them can be removed. you can determine the active one by clicking help>troubleshootinginformation, then scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' . you will then be in File Explorer and will see the name. Once you do that, click the imap folder and do screenshot of the message folders for each account. Do the same for your Mail folder (if you have POP accounts).

content:
Right-click the account in the Folder Pane, Subscribe..., Refresh, subscribe the missing folders. Subscribe the Sent Mail folder, as that is where sent mail is copied automatically (uncheck 'Place a copy in' in Account Settings, Copies & Folders). Most users unsubscribe All Mail, as it includes mail that is already shown in other folders.

If you follow gmail's recommendation to 'Just mark it as deleted' in Account Settings, Server Settings, subscribe to Trash but unsubscribe Deleted Items.

If you save drafts on the IMAP server, the situation is a bit confusing, but the best option is described here. If you don't access drafts from multiple devices, save them in Local Folders (same with Templates).
creator: sfhowes

content:
What sfhowes said. There shouldn't be a Deleted Items folder there, not sure why he mentions that, and there is nothing special about the Drafts folder, but yeah, you'll need to subscribe to the missing folders.

There seems to be something amiss there, though…

You shouldn't have to manually subscribe to those folders, you should be subscribed by default after setting up the account. You didn't have to do that with your other Gmail accounts, did you? And interestingly enough, you appear to be subscribed to the All Mail folder, which is precisely the folder that you'd better not subscribe to.

What version of Thunderbird are you using? Although Gmail IMAP server puts the standard folders in a [Gmail] hierarchy, since Thunderbird 115 that folder hierarchy is hidden from the user in the folder pane. Folders are supposed to appear there now as if they were at the same level as the Inbox, and the [Gmail] folder shouldn't be visible there. But you appear to have that messed up. The [Gmail] folder, which if visible should appear at the same level as Inbox, in your case appears as a subfolder of it, and the All Mail folder, which (if subscribed) should appear either as a subfolder of [Gmail] (if visible) or as a separate All Mail folder (if not), in your case appears as a mix of those two cases, i.e. a separate [Gmail]All Mail folder with the "[Gmail]" prefix in the name…

So although it seems you'll have to manually subscribe to those folders in order for them to appear in Thunderbird, there is clearly something amiss there, but I don't know what's causing it nor how to fix it other than maybe deleting the account (both info and data) and setting it up again…

And you said you cannot choose All Folders under View > Folders in the menu bar? I suppose that means you have Unified Folders ticked… What happens if you choose that option to untick it? That should cause All Folders to be selected instead…
creator: DavidGG

creator: emile.gaudinot

content:
The emails are only in the folder "All messages".

Ahh… This is a Gmail account, right? Now, that's some relevant information you didn't mention before…

Gmail doesn't work like a normal IMAP server would, and one of its many particularities is that mail clients cannot directly remove mail from the All Mail folder. You may accomplish that indirectly by moving the messages to Bin/Trash first (has to be the same Bin/Trash as the one used by Gmail for this to work), and then remove the messages from there or just let Gmail automatically do that after 30 days.

If you want to remove the messages directly from there without having to move them to Bin/Trash first, you can only do that from Gmail, cannot do it with Thunderbird or any other mail client.
creator: DavidGG

content:
Bonjour,

biloubil said
est il possible q un développeur ai pensé à un manière de sauvegarder les comptes paramétrés dans Thunderbird ?

Tous les paramètres des comptes (POP et/ou IMAP) sont stockées dans le fichier central prefs.js dans le dossier de profil de Thunderbird. Je viens de le tester : créer un nouveau profil puis fermer TB. Copier le fichier prefs.js d'un autre profil existant et fonctionnant avec la même version de Thunderbird et le coller dans le dossier du nouveau profil à la place du fichier prefs.js vierge. Redémarrer et tous les comptes sont là ! Évidemment il faut renseigner tous les mots de passe de tous le comptes mais là aussi on peut copier/coller les fichiers où sont sauvegardés les mots passe. Autre inconvénient : pour les comptes POP il faut transférer les fichiers de messages depuis l'autre profil

biloubil said
et ne me parler pas du dossier profil puisque d une version a l'autre cela ne fonctionne plus! (je viens d en faire les frais !)

content:
I need to ask a few questions to understand the current situation.

re : lost my app for Mozilla thunderbird

What OS are you using? Did you need to reinstall the OS? Did you need to reinstall the Thunderbird program ? Where did you get the download for the Thunderbird program eg: from official webpage here: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ or via the Windows app ?

Check Firewall: Exit Thunderbird if running Access Firewall - it might be the default that comes with computer or it might be controlled by an Anti-Virus product you installed. Thunderbird must be set up as an allowed program otherwise it might get blocked by Firewall. We need to rule out this as the issue. So, please confirm - Thunderbird has been set up as an allowed program.

If yes, you needed to reinstall the OS Did Windows OS create a folder called 'windows.old' on the C: drive ? If yes: Select that 'windows.old' folder to see contents. Does that 'windows.old' folder contain something in this location: C://Users/Username/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird/..... OR if you installed program using Windows app store: The Microsoft Store version is located in a different place. C://Users/UsernameAppData\Local\Packages\MozillaThunderbird.MZLA_h5892qc0xkpca\LocalCache\Roaming

This will tell if all your profile etc has been saved and can be recovered.

When you run Thunderbird, does it locate your old profile and emails etc, but then fails to connect to server? If yes: What have you got in this location: In Thunderbird Help > Troubleshooting Information Scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts' Copy all data and paste into this question.

If you reinstalled Thunderbird and now you are asked to create a new mail account in a new profile but having a problem.... Please post an image showing what it shows when you are trying to create the account. Tell me what server you ar trying to connect to...eg: Comcast, BT, yahoo, gmail etc

Please check current password: Please attempt to logon to your webmail account via a browser using the password you believe to be correct. If you get access, then you know your password is accurate. Do you get access to your webmail account?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re :If I do an auto populate attempt,

Does this mean you removed the Imap account and are now attempting to recreate the account ? If yes, then after entering Name, Email address and Password clickon 'Continue' It attempts to locate configuration Then click on 'Configure Manually' button And check everything is correctly set up as server settings stated below.


Please recheck everything - look for typos - make sure Username is full email address. Here are the settings:

IMAP server settings:

  • Server name : mail.twc.com
  • Port : 993
  • Connection Security : SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username = full email address
  • Password = same password you use to access webmail

SMTP server settings:

  • Server name : mail.twc.com
  • Port : 587
  • Connection Security : STARTTLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username = full email address
  • Password = same password you use to access webmail

After you have carefully rechecked everything including what you see in : Settings > Privacy & Security 'Saved Passwords' imap://account.... and smtp://account... Both need to show correct Username as full email address and Password - identical for incoming and outgoing and must be same as used to access webmail.

Then Exit Thunderbird so it can be forced to update files.

Whilst Thunderbird is closed.... check Firewall This might be the default that came with computer or one controlled by an Anti-Virus you installed. Thunderbird must be set up as an allowed program. You do not want the Firewall blocking anything. Confirm Thunderbird is set up as an allowed app.

Then start Thunderbird and report on results.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Solved it late at night... It turns out it was a Spectrum server issue. The stock reply I kept getting was it was "a known Mozilla Thunderbird error." After doing what you described above, and five days of arguing with tech support for escalation to a supervisor/competent tech, I got to a person who listened to me and understood my testing results. Spectrum changed to a "one password to rule them all" policy scheme. The tech pulled in a server engineer and even got them to check the server logs. It was determined that the issue was two fold.... took fifteen minutes total to fix....

First, their password scheme assumed the TWC server password would accept the same special characters as the website password. However, the TWC server only accepts !@#$%-_ special characters, fewer than the website.

Second, they scheme is supposed to update the server password when you update your website password. It turns out it does not update the TWC server password at all.

So let it be known at this time the TWC servers' passwords have to be updated/reset by hand and it is a specific group separate from the regular path of support that does it. It is now written in my account notes that this group needs to address a password reset on the TWC server. The tech wrote up a report but can not guarantee that the changes needed will be made to the scheme.

AA
creator: teknikal

content:
Many thanks @technikal, this was the solution after days of frustration trying to access my old roadrunner account. Tech support from Spectrum was limited to the scripted, "we don't support 3rd party client software" response. They absolutely refused to help troubleshoot.

I having been using Thunderbird reliably for over 7 years. I recently upgraded my desktop and when I tried starting up Thunderbird I got the - couldn't login error message. I knew the problem had to be on the Spectrum end because I could see their server respond to Thunderbird probe for email server configurations. I tried disabling all Microsoft Windows 11 security features without success. I had a suspicion that the TWC mail server password may not be the same as the web mail server but Spectrum support said use the webmail password. When I read this post, I tried an old password and voila! - login successful! A couple of years ago when I changed my Spectrum webmail password, their TWC mail server was still using my old password. They aren't synched.
creator: Dpryan0

content:
Abusix is a system that identifies IP addresses that are associated with spam and other such nefarious (?) practices. The email was rejected because the SMTP server identified the source (your computer) as having that IP address.

IP addresses are usually reassigned upon a reboot so it is often easily remedied. To find your IP address, search for "what is my ip address?" and use one of the free services. It should match the IP address on the error message when it occurs.

content: I can't see that you've stated whether the email clients are IMAP or POP3 or which OS you're running so, if you're running Windows 10 or higher, go to: C:\Users\[Users]\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\XXXX.default-release then Mail or IMapMail depending on your set up and see if there is a 'Local Folders' folder. Are there files in here? Specifically, are there two 'Unsent Messages' files?
creator: frisée

content: The Mail folder would still be present, and that's where Local Folders should be within the profile folder, even if the accounts are IMAP, because that's where Thunderbird puts all the mail stored locally on the computer.
creator: DavidGG

content:
In the menu bar, choose View > Folders > Folder Pane Header if not already ticked, to make that visible. Then, click on the '···' button to the right of the '+ New Message' button in that pane to display a list of options. One of the options available there near the bottom should be Hide Local Folders, which you have probably ticked, select it to untick it and make the Local Folders appear in the folder pane.

The following article shows the Folder Pane Header and explains the options available there:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/new-thunderbird-115-supernova#w_look-and-feel-improvements-new-message-button-get-messages-folder-pane-options-meatball-menu
creator: DavidGG

This is a community support forum and please keep your replies in your thread vs creating new threads to make a reply as your thread is https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1488087

To post a reply in a thread that is not locked, scroll down to the Post a Reply box, type in your reply then click on Post Reply.

Locking as it is harder for people to help you in having to follow your threads as replies.

content: Are you talking about the master password? In that case, you could try the following: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/protect-your-thunderbird-passwords-primary-password#w_reset-your-primary-password-if-you-have-forgotten-it
creator: shipman

content:
Ronald,

It appears that you did mark the response as "helpful" or solved the problem. If you were to more information here, which might be able to help.


See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/password-manager-remember-delete-change-tb and https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/protect-your-thunderbird-passwords-primary-password

Be aware if Thunderbird just started asking for your password it is unlikely it "forgot" but that connection to the sever using the password is has was rejected. It may have deleted the password after multiple failed attempts (and clicking cancel on the request for a password), but I really don't recall a time when it actually "forgot". That would require a rather serious bug.

Also, some requests for a password mean you have a security product/antivirus that has messed up post an update resulting in no mail. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/cannot-receive-messages

If you solved this, posting your results might help someone else.
